speech.para: One of the things that the Howard government promised during the last election campaign was that it would extend the contracts with Australia Post to provide electronic banking services to small regional communities. I am pleased to say that Mrs Elaine Kenny, who is the postmaster in Roseworthy, has successfully bid for the giroPost services approved for the township of Roseworthy. She put out a petition to see how many people need this service. In two weeks, 273 people from this township came to the post office and recorded the fact that they wanted, needed and would use this service, as one of the regional communities in Wakefield. I am pleased that, under the program of bank and post initiatives that the Howard government has put in place, Roseworthy and about four other townships in Wakefield will receive electronic banking services via the contract with the post office.

The government is providing some $9.7 million over four years to make these services available to an extra 266 post offices. For Roseworthy, this is a good step forward. It is an initiative that is in keeping with the history of the town, a town where John Ridley invented the Ridley Stripper, which transformed the wheat industry in South Australia. I believe that this initiative of the Howard government will transform the ability of people in regional Australia to be able to access online or electronic banking services.

talk.start.para: âI take this opportunity to raise once again the paucity of Telstraâs broadband services in my electorate of Swan. A week ago Mr Kel Watkins, the owner of Freightshop, wrote to me to explain the appalling behaviour of Telstra in relation to a request from his business to install a broadband service. In his letter Mr Watkins explains the situation:

quote.para: We are a small freight-forwarding company based at the International Airport in Perth. In spite of repeated requests of Telstra, we still cannot get broadband connection. We are situated between Qantas and the International Post office in Affleck Road.

Last October, Australian Customs brought their Customs Interactive System online for all exporters to communicate directly with them. This programme is internet based and was written for the two platforms they assumed all freight forwarders would have. One was Windows XP and the other was broadband. Windows XP was easy to get. Broadband was not.

We are online with Customs all day every day of the working week and the connections are so slow that we can wait 10 to 15 minutes just to log on. To move from one screen to the next can take up to two minutes. I have had to filter out all emails over 500 kilobits because, if an email arrives, the Customs programme just stops operating. Unfortunately, some business related emails do not get downloaded until I can take a computer home and use my broadband connection in Hilton to receive the dayâs business.

speech.para: As Mr Watkins said, it is a deplorable situation that in mid-2005 a business within 400 metres of an international airport is denied access to broadband. Unfortunately, this is far from the only complaint I have had in my electorate from businesses and households who cannot access basic broadband services from Telstra. Often the situation is just as farcical as that related by Mr Watkins. I have had many complaints from people in Swan about Telstraâs often-used tactic of promising residents access to broadband on a trial basis, delivering that service for the period of the trial and then informing customersâlo and beholdâthat, despite being able to provide broadband, the service is not available on a permanent basis. In many cases, residents have actually changed internet providers to take advantage of the Telstra trial, only to find that the service is not available in the long term.

I can understand why there is much concern in the context of the sale of Telstra about services in rural and regional Australia. Having been a farmer myself for some six years in Western Australia, I sympathise with the need to ensure that services in rural Australia are up to scratch, but I think that the political preoccupation of the Howard government with services in the bush has overshadowed the needs of those who live in the cities, as was pointed out yesterday by the member for Lindsay. Telstraâs failure to deliver adequate broadband to my electorate is an indictment of its infrastructure investment program.

You would expect that, at present, when Telstra is under the spotlight given its proposed sale, the company would be moving heaven and earth to improve its services throughout Australia. You would expect Telstra to be currently demonstrating its corporate âbest behaviourâ. If this is best behaviour, the only conclusion that can be drawn is that it is far from good enough. It is vital that the government undertake to deliver broadband to all Australians. That should be the overriding objective of the government in the debate about telecommunications. At the end of the day, if the only way to ensure that this objective is met is to require a minimum broadband service under the universal service obligation, then so be it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to advise the previous speaker, the member for Swan, Mr Wilkie, that all Australians have access to broadband and a phone service right nowâ
âRubbish! That is absolutely untrue! Itâs untrue.
âno matter where they are in the Commonwealth of Australia.

speech.para: Townsville has been put in the spotlight by media outlets across Australia in the past few weeks, but for the wrong reasons. Once again, the Townsville Hospital has made the headlines. The Morris inquiry was held in Townsville last week and uncovered even more disturbing issues. The inquiry exposed the fact that a psychiatrist with forged qualifications was able to work at the hospitalâs mental health unit and treat patients. Just as disturbing was the fact that Queensland Health covered it up. I ask the question: is this the only thing that it has covered up? Of course not. However, I was just as disappointed to hear that the Morris inquiry highlighted the ongoing issue of workplace bullying, increased workloads and low morale in the Townsville Hospital. But it appears that Townsville Hospital is just one of the many hospitals around Queensland suffering from underfunding and understaffing by the Beattie government.

I must say, I was disappointed that the allegations of Medicare fraud occurring at the Townsville Hospital were not brought up at the Morris inquiry. If these allegations are true, then it is not just fraud on the Australian government; it is also fraud on the patients involved. Now the hospital is being investigated by the Australian government, Queensland Health, CMC and the Health Insurance Commission into Medicare fraud claims. Just yesterday, the new Queensland health minister was unable to answer a straightforward question about his policy on secret waiting lists or what advice he would give to waiting patients. He could not give an answer to the Liberalsâ question. The Liberal shadow minister for health, Dr Bruce Flegg, tabled documents showing that the Queensland government had introduced a second secret waiting list for some categories of surgeryâanother example of Mr Beattie putting the dollar at the top of his list of priorities, rather than patientsâ lives.

The Townsville Hospital differs from other hospitals around the state because it delivers care to patients from all over North Queensland and as far away as Papua New Guinea. For some time the hospital has been 100 per cent full, 100 per cent of the time. Last month, the hospital was forced to cancel surgery cases. I put the blame squarely on the shoulders of the Beattie government for letting down the people of North Queensland. An extra $23 million is needed now to address the overcrowding at the Townsville Hospital. Despite this desperate need for the hospital to be provided with proper funding, the state government provided no funding in their latest budget. Once again, Townsville was overlooked in favour of the south-east corner.

The list of the problems with the stateâs health system continues to grow, while the people of North Queensland continue to suffer from inadequate public health care. However, instead of taking up the challenge, Mr Beattie continues to concentrate on the wrong priorities. This week Mr Beattie attempted to take the spotlight off the stateâs health crisis in another of his media stunts and instead put the focus on the Australian governmentâs proposed industrial relations reforms. I call on Mr Beattie to step up to the challenge and concentrate on fixing the real problems facing his constituents. These latest incidents strengthen the argument that it is perhaps time for the Australian government to take over the Queensland hospital system.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The honourable memberâs time has expired. In accordance with sessional order 193, the time for membersâ statements has concluded.

debateinfo.title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (PROTECTION OF SUBMARINE CABLES AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Mr Entsch:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âLabor supports the Telecommunications and Other Legislation Amendment (Protection of Submarine Cables and Other Measures) Bill 2005. This bill is the product of extensive consultation and addresses a pressing need to better protect critically important submarine fibre optic telecommunications cables. As was noted by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources during earlier debate on this bill, the overseas voice and data traffic that travels over these cables is worth more than $5 billion a year to the Australian economy.

speech.para: Around 99 per cent of international data and voice traffic entering and leaving Australia is transported on submarine optical fibre cables. On top of this, the majority of this traffic is carried on just a handful of these submarine telecommunications cables. As such, any damage to one of these major submarine cables that prevented the cable from being able to carry traffic would cause dramatic disruption and delays to data and voice transmissions into and out of Australia. Such disruptions and delays would have a dramatic impact not only on the cable owners but also on the productivity of all Australian businesses relying on international data transmission.

In todayâs information economy, this would include almost every business in Australia, whether directly affected immediately by any sort of damage or indirectly, because they are associated with some other business which is affected. In summary, these cables are so important to the Australian economy that not even a fully privatised Telstra would be silly enough to allow them to fall into disrepairâat least, we hope that would be the case.

Despite their importance, these submarine cables are currently not adequately protected by the Australian telecommunications regulatory regime. Submarine telecommunications cables in Australian waters are currently vulnerable to damage from a multitude of activities, including trawling, anchoring and dredging. While the locations of these submarine telecommunications cables are well known and are marked on most maritime maps, accidents causing damage to cables have occurred in the past. The fact that these cables have been damaged on a number of occasions, despite their critical importance to the Australian economy, indicates that the existing regulatory regime is not up to the job of protecting these important pieces of national infrastructure.

The existing Submarine Cables and Pipelines Protection Act 1963 provides only nominal deterrence to the public engaging in activities that might risk damaging such a cable. The current penalties for causing damage to this critical infrastructure are a maximum fine of just $2,000 or imprisonment for just 12 months. When you consider just how important this critical infrastructure is to Australiaâs economy, these paltry sums and sentences seem woefully inadequate. These penalties are clearly not in proportion to the consequences of causing damage to these cables.

The existing legislation is also limited to retrospective sanctions for damage to cables and does not include any substantive prospective arrangements for prevention of damage in the first instance. The Telecommunications and Other Legislation Amendment (Protection of Submarine Cables and Other Measures) Bill 2005 attempts to remedy this situation. The bill increases the level of protection provided for submarine cables, by allowing the Australian Communications and Media Authority to declare protection zones around cables of national significance.

The bill further prohibits certain activities within protection zones that are likely to damage the relevant cables, such as trawling, dredging, mining and any work done around those critical areas. The bill permits other activities that pose a lesser threat to the integrity of these cablesâsuch as mid-sea fishing; the installation of wharves, jetties and boat ramps; and the laying of electricity cables, gas pipelines and suchâaccording to conditions prescribed by the ACMA.

The Australian Federal Police will be responsible for policing the prohibitions, which is a vast improvement on the current state of affairs under which the owners of these submarine cables support advisory patrols of the areas surrounding the cables to attempt to head off any activities that may cause damage. That is a situation which is untenable in the long term and does not provide the sort of protection that is necessary in the current environment to protect this critical infrastructure for Australia.

The creation of protection zones, as opposed to simply imposing fines for causing damage, has the added benefit of encouraging the builders of smaller cables to co-locate their cables in the protection zones to enjoy the protection provided by that area and that zoning. This co-location will produce further benefits in the future by increasing the coordination of the laying of submarine fibre-optic cables in Australia. It is likely that, once a protection zone is established for the benefit of a cable of national significance, other cable owners will see the benefits of installing their submarine cables within the boundaries of the protection zone in order to piggyback on the benefits of protection provided by those zones. This effect will, hopefully, avoid the spaghetti bowl style installations of these cables that have emerged in countries like the United States. It is unlikely that the creation of these protection zones will have a substantial impact on coastal communities and those who use the sea and seabed in affected areas.

Protection zones can only be created around cables of national significance. As such, very few areas will be affected by this legislation: possibly as few as 10 cables of national significance will be covered by the legislation. Further, before a protection zone may be declared by the ACMA, the ACMA is required to consult with users of the sea and seabed in the affected area through an advisory committee that will include representation from affected parties. Before declaring a protection zone, ACMA will have to develop and publish a protection zone proposal and invite and consider public comment on that proposal. Labor considers that the bill makes adequate provision for ensuring that affected parties are consulted about the establishment of protection zones.

The bill includes heavy penalties for engaging in prohibited activities within the protection zones. These penalties are broadly in line with those that apply in Australia for damaging analogous submarine infrastructureâfor example, penalties for damaging submarine gas pipelines or electricity lines. Bringing these penalties into line in this way is appropriate, as telecommunications infrastructure is just as important to the Australian economy as resources infrastructure is. Australiaâs telecommunications and IT industries are two of the most important sectors of the Australian economy. These cables are their connection to the international marketâif you like, their lifeline to those marketsâalthough, given Australiaâs current $19 billion information technology trade deficit, there is clearly far more information coming into Australia through these pipes than is going out.

The bill provides that the owners of the submarine cables will be able to seek compensation for any loss caused by a person damaging a submarine cable. This statutory right of compensation will clear up some existing jurisdictional uncertainties with respect to the rights of submarine cable owners and provide increased certainty of investment for these operators.

In summary, this bill is a sensible approach to addressing a longstanding risk to the Australian telecommunications sector. The Labor Party would be happy if the government protected all Australian telecommunications infrastructure this well instead of allowing Telstra to run down its rural network in a bid to maximise the governmentâs return from its efforts to force through the sale of Telstra. Unfortunately, we in the Australian Labor Party realise that this is far too much to ask of this government, which is out of touch on this issue. It is something that we see not only daily out in the community but also now in the Senate when we see the sort of bullying tactics of people such as Senator Heffernanâ

talk.start.para: Mr Anthony Smith interjectingâ
âIt is telecommunications infrastructure and protection under this bill.
(Hon. IR Causley)âActually the bill is about undersea cables. It is not about telecommunications. The member for Oxley will speak to the bill.

âFor the sake of the Main Committee, I might just read out the name of the bill: telecommunications and other legislation amendment bill. Unfortunately, as I said, we in the Labor Party understand that it is just too much to askâ

âI assure the member for Oxley that I have read the second reading speech and looked through the explanatory memorandum. It is a very specific bill about undersea cables, and the member for Oxley will speak to the bill.
âWith that in mind, as I said, this is good legislation and the Labor Party does support it. It is just notâ
Mr Anthony Smith interjectingâ

âIt is. That is what I am talking about. If other legislation were as good as this in terms of actually protecting critical telecommunications infrastructure, such as services provided to the country in rural and regional areas, we would all be a lot happier. The Labor Party would be happy to support good legislation that gave other areas the sorts of protections that we find in this bill. But, as we heard earlier, the government is just not in touch with the community, particularly when it comes to broadband telecommunications.

speech.para: With that in mind, we will support the bill before the House, as it is vital to Australiaâs infrastructure. It is a rare piece of telecommunications legislation from this government: it will actually be of benefit to the Australian public. With that in mind, we fully support the bill.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to support the Telecommunications and Other Legislation Amendment (Protection of Submarine Cables and Other Measures) Bill 2005, an important piece of legislation proposed by this government. I say âimportantâ because at this stage we are concerned about the lack of security for submarine fibre-optic telecommunications cables. There has been extensive consultation with and broad support from stakeholders for this bill, and a number of internal regulatory models have been examined.

speech.para: This bill establishes for the first time a regulatory regime to protect submarine telecommunications cables that link Australia to global networks which are vital to the national economy. It also changes the arrangements for payment of compensation in the event of an acquisition of property under provisions of the Telecommunications Act 1997. It will provide benefits to the fishing industry and other users of the sea and seabed by clarifying the responsibilities of both carriers and users, and by encouraging co-location of telecommunications cables.

There are nine submarine cables landing in Australia which carry almost all of our international voice and data traffic and are worth more than $5 billion a year to the economy. There are currently three cables which may satisfy requirements to be designated âcables of national significanceâ. They are: the Australia-Japan cable, which links Sydney to Japan and then the US; the Southern Cross cable network, which links Sydney with New Zealand and Fiji and then the US; and the SEA-ME-WE3 cable that links Perth with Jakarta, Singapore and then Europe.

A protection zone will reach from the shore to the limit of Australiaâs exclusive economic zone or to the edge of the continental shelf, whichever is further. This will span state-controlled coastal waters, up to three nautical miles from shore; Commonwealth-controlled territorial seas, up to 12 nautical miles; and the economic exclusive zone, up to 200 nautical miles. A nominal location is used as it may not be possible to specify exactly the location of a submarine cable over its full length. In the case of a single cable of national significance, a protection zone area consists of an area not more than one nautical mile either side of the cable. In the case of more than one cable of national significance, a protection zone area will consist of the area between each cable and not more than one nautical mile from the outside edge of each of the outermost cables.

The cables are easily damaged by ships anchoring and trawling operations. They are expensive and time consuming to repair. Submarine cables have been damaged several times in recent years. This causes enormous disruption and we need this legislation to effectively protect against that. This legislation allows the Australian Communications and Media Authority, ACMA, to determine protection zones. The zones would extend a nautical mile either side of the cables and run to the edge of the Australian exclusive economic zone.

The legislation restricts or prohibits marine activities in protection zones, with heavy penalties applying for damaging submarine cables or engaging in any prohibited activities in those areas. Under the bill, the penalty for damaging cables in a protection zone can be up to 600 penalty units and 10 years imprisonment. The current penalties are very limited and minimal. The prohibited activities include fishing where equipment operates near the seabed, anchoring, dredging and mining.

The final component of this legislation is to make it clear that carriers are liable to pay any just term compensation arising as a result of a successful claim of acquisition of property. It will be an offence in a protected zone to damage a submarine cable, to negligently damage a submarine cable or to engage in any of those prohibited or restricted activities as specified by ACMA in the protection zone declaration. As the volume of international voice and data traffic increases, and as Australian businesses become ever more globalised, the need for reliable international communications links will increase. It is right that the government proposes this bill, as it is a matter of national importance. We must be involved in the protection of these cables, which are literally our links to our international partners.

This contrasts markedly, however, with the need for government to be involved in the provision of domestic infrastructure for telecommunications, except perhaps where there is not a commercial market. There is no place for government in a developed country in the telecommunications market. We ought to remove ourselves from the telecommunications industry and allow for true competition to improve services and move the technology forward. The introduction of new technology into the more remote locations of Australia has in recent times been improved markedly by the introduction of direct-tendering processesâa transparent system whereby the taxpayers of this country have provided for those additional services in remote Australia. The latest experience in that regard, of course, in 2001 saw the introduction, for the first time, of untimed local calls to some 38,000 subscribers in the most remote parts of Australia. That was a service introduced by this government in a transparent process. Tenders were called, and for the sum of $150 million those 38,000 remote area telephone clients had untimed local calls for the first time.

Thus, when it comes to the provision of improved technology for communications in Australia, it will not be at the behest of or as a result of some charitable act by a telco in Australia. It will be because backbenchers will consider that their constituents require the most updated communication processes available, will argue their case through the proper process and will convince ministers and colleagues that taxpayersâ funds ought to be spent.

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Kalgoorlie is now starting to stray from the bill.

âThose funds, hopefully, will be spent. I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your warning to stay on topic. I simply make the point, of course, that telcos are not charitable organisations and will always be concerned with commercialism.
âI am sorry. I have warned the member for Oxley. The member for Kalgoorlie will come back to the bill.

âWe of course are discussing a different topic here today. That is, as a good government, our concern for the protection of very important international communications infrastructure that, quite rightly, ought to be the responsibility of good governance. We propose this legislation, then, to secure this vital infrastructure and to protect it in such a way that all those participating in the area will know beforehand exactly what the exclusion zone is and what the penalties might be for breaching that exclusion zone, so that we create a more informed industry when it comes to marine operations, fishing, mining et cetera. All will be forewarned as to the significance of this vital infrastructure and the penalties for breaching such exclusion zones. It gives me a great deal of pleasure to strongly support this bill today.

âIt is my pleasure to sum up the debate on the Telecommunications and Other Legislation Amendment (Protection of Submarine Cables and Other Measures) Bill 2005 this morning. At the outset, I want to thank those members who have contributed to this debate. This bill creates a regulatory scheme to enable the Australian Communications and Media Authority, otherwise known as the ACMA, to establish protection zones over submarine telecommunications cables that link Australia to global networks and that are vital to our national economy.

speech.para: I would like to briefly reiterate the importance of this bill and emphasise why the government is committed to protecting this vital infrastructure. Nine submarine telecommunications cables carry almost all of Australiaâs overseas voice and data traffic and are worth more than $5 billion a year to the Australian economy. Three of these cablesâtwo landing in Sydney and one in Perthâare currently of particular significance to the Australian economy because of their high capacity.

These cables are vulnerable to damage by operations such as the anchoring of ships, certain types of fishing, the dumping of materials at sea, dredging and other activities that take place on the seabed where these cables are laid. Submarine cables have been damaged several times in recent years. Repairing broken or damaged cables is an expensive and time-consuming exercise. Cable damage or breakage impedes information flow, which affects the capacity of Australians and particularly Australian businesses to conduct international transactions and affairs.

The volume of overseas communicationsâvoice and data, both business and personalâis increasing and will continue to do so in the future. Thus any disruption of Australiaâs communication links with the world can cause delays, disruptions and unnecessary costs, not only to the owners of the cables but to the many people who rely on them for their daily business affairs.

Under this bill, the ACMA will be authorised to declare protection zones over submarine cables of national significance. Within these protection zones, activities that are particularly dangerous to submarine cables will be prohibited. Other, less dangerous activities will be restricted. Passage of this bill will establish a protection regime for telecommunications submarine cables that will provide a comprehensive and transparent process for the protection of these nationally significant cables.

I thank honourable members for their support of the Telecommunications and Other Legislation Amendment (Protection of Submarine Cables and Other Measures) Bill 2005. I welcome the support given by both sides of the parliament.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Ordered that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 16 November 2004:

item.para: How many individuals have reached the Medicare Safety Net Threshold during (a) 2003, and (b) 2004 in (i) Victoria, and (ii) the electoral division of Scullin.

How many individuals have reached the Medicare Safety Net Threshold during (a) 2003, and (b) 2004 in the postcode area (i) 3074, (ii) 3075, (iii) 3076, (iv) 3082, (v) 3083, (vi) 3087, (vii) 3088, (viii) 3089, (ix) 3090, (x) 3091, and (xi) 3752.

item.para: Notes to the Statistics
The statistics relate to services that were rendered on a âfee-for-serviceâ basis for which benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in 2002, 2003 and 2004.

Since the statistics sought relate to (services provided) âin â¦â the statistics were compiled from Medicare data by servicing provider postcode. Medicare statistics by electorate published on the Department of Health and Ageing web site were compiled from patient enrolment postcode data.

In compiling the statistics, where a postcode overlapped electoral boundaries, the data were allocated to electorate using a concordance file derived from population census data. This can result in some data being erroneously allocated to an adjoining electorate. Data have been excluded if postcodes were not present on the concordance file.

Caution should be exercised in interpreting Medicare statistics by region of provider. Electorates containing major hospitals and health facilities and electorates that encompass major regional centres will have higher rates of service provision.

item.para: Notes to the Tables:

The most recently published statistics on individuals and families who have reached Extended Medicare Safety Net thresholds, and on Extended Medicare Safety Net benefits, have regard to claims processed by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) up to and including 31 July 2004. Statistics relating to families registered are as at 29 August 2004.
The statistics were compiled from postcode level data (postcode of the head of the household, otherwise postcode of the oldest member of the family) and are based on 2001 electorate boundaries.

Where a postcode overlapped electorate boundaries, statistics were allocated to electorate using a concordance file derived from population census data. This can result in some data being erroneously allocated to an adjoining electorate. Data for people using post office boxes or private mail bags are excluded from electorate reporting as this cannot be appropriately allocated. Data have also been excluded if postcodes were not present on the concordance files.

The statistics on families and individuals who appear to have reached the Safety Net thresholds, include families and individuals who need to verify that they have paid the full fee charged, where claims have been lodged with the HIC prior to paying the treating practitioner (unsubstantiated claims).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 8Â February 2005:

item.para: How many Australian Federal Police (AFP) officers were deployed overseas during 2004.
What was the highest number of AFP officers that were deployed overseas during 2004 at any given time.

In respect of the AFP officers deployed overseas, what was the name and location (including city/town and State) of the AFP investigation, inquiry, team, squad or unit from which each officer was seconded.

In respect of each AFP investigation, inquiry, team, squad or unit which released an officer or officers to be deployed overseas, how many officers were in it at the commencement of (a) 2004 and (b) 2005.
How many AFP officers were permanently based in Western Australia on (a) 5 January 2004 and (b)Â 3 January 2005.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: In 2004 the AFP deployed 938 employees to overseas missions. This figure includes Protective Service Officers. Additional employees travelled overseas to conduct extraditions, to present at or attend international seminars and conferences, or to conduct operational duties in relation to Australian-based investigations.

The highest number of AFP employees deployed overseas was 408 during the fortnight ending 11 August 2004. This number includes all employees deployed to meet the AFPâs commitments to peacekeeping, capacity building activities, major international incidents and the International Network.

Due to the fluid nature of AFP operations, exact numbers of members attached to specific investigations, inquiries, teams, squads or units are not available. Employees deployed overseas from each regional office for the period 1 January â 31 December 2004 to conduct peacekeeping, capacity building, attend major international incidents and the International Network are as follows:

The above figures do not include additional employees travelling overseas to conduct extraditions, operational duties relating to Australian based investigations, presentations or those attending international seminars. Furthermore, specified periods of deployment vary extensively due to operational requirements.

Due to the fluid nature of AFP operations, exact numbers of members attached to specific investigations, inquiries, teams, squads or units are not available. Staffing resources deployed to each regional office are as follows:

item.label: (b)
item.para: January 2005

entry.para: 244Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

item.label: (a)
item.para: On 5 January 2004, 139 members of the AFP and 74 officers from the Australian Protective Service were permanently deployed to Western Australia.

item.label: (b)
item.para: On 3 January 2005, 140 members of the AFP and 103 officers from the AFP - Protective Service were permanently deployed to Western Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 16 March 2005:

quote.para: How many people in the electoral division of Shortland had been in receipt of Newstart Allowance for 5 years or more (a) in 1996, (b) in 1998, (c) in 2000, (d) in 2001, (e) in 2002, (f) in 2003, (g) in 2004, and (h) on 14 March 2005.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Comparable data for the period 1996 to 1998 is not readily available for Newstart Allowance. Although you requested data for Newstart Allowance recipients of five years or more as at 14Â March 2005, for data consistency reasons, and to provide you with the most up-to-date figures, I have provided information as at MayÂ 2005.

entry.para: Newstart Allowance Customers in the electoral division of Shortland with income support durations of five years or more

quote.para: 2000 â 2005 data provides the number of Newstart Allowance customers with income support duration of 5 years or more as at May of each year.
Data was extracted from Newstart Superstar Database using postcodes for 2004 Electorate Boundaries, and cleared by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations on 23 June 2005.
The historical data has therefore been extracted using 2004 Electorate postcodes.
Counts for electorate may be slightly undercounted
Single counts <20 have been excluded from totals

NOTES: It is important not to equate the Newstart Allowance income support population data with the number of unemployed persons, as defined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in line with International Labour Organisation guidelines. As there are a number of significant definitional differences the two series cannot be directly compared.

The standard definition of payment duration in relation to Newstart Allowance recipients is their income support payment duration, which is different from the duration of unemployment as used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. In many cases the duration of unemployment under the Australian Bureau of Statistics definition will be much shorter than the duration of income support receipt.
2000 â 2005 data provides the number of Newstart Allowance customers with income support duration of 5 years or more as at May of each year.
Data was extracted from Newstart Superstar Database using postcodes for 2004 Electorate Boundaries, and cleared by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations on 23 June 2005.
The historical data has therefore been extracted using 2004 Electorate postcodes.
Counts for electorate may be slightly undercounted
Single counts <20 have been excluded from totals

NOTES: It is important not to equate the Newstart Allowance income support population data with the number of unemployed persons, as defined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in line with International Labour Organisation guidelines. As there are a number of significant definitional differences the two series cannot be directly compared.

The standard definition of payment duration in relation to Newstart Allowance recipients is their income support payment duration, which is different from the duration of unemployment as used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. In many cases the duration of unemployment under the Australian Bureau of Statistics definition will be much shorter than the duration of income support receipt.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: For each year since 2002, how many (a) general practitioners, (b) other Medicare providers, and (c) specialists were there in (i) the electoral division of Fowler, (ii) Sydney, (iii) New South Wales, and (iv) Australia.

For each year since 2002, what was the ratio per 1000 head of population of (a) general practitioners, (b) other Medicare providers, and (c) specialists in (i) the electoral division of Fowler, (ii) Sydney, (iii) New South Wales, and (iv) Australia.

For each year since 2002, how many (a) general practitioners, (b) other Medicare providers, and (c) specialists were there in the local government area of the (i) City of Fairfield, (ii) City of Liverpool.

For each year since 2002, what was the ratio per 1000 head of population of (a) general practitioners, (b) other Medicare providers, and (c) specialists in the local government areas of (i) City of Fairfield, (ii) City of Liverpool.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: The authoritative source of information on specialists is the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (AIHW) which both receives registration renewal data from each state and territory medical board, and conducts regular surveys. AIHW data is free and can be accessed on their web site [www.aihw.gov.au]. This information is not broken down by region. Specialists are a mobile workforce, with many areas receiving specialist services from visiting specialists based in other areas. Neither AIHW nor the Department of Health and Ageing have any data which would enable this to be quantified.

General practice workforce statistics are compiled on a financial year basis and are derived on the basis of servicing provider postcode. The numbers of Vocationally Registered General Practitioners and Other Medical Practitioners have been combined into General Practitioners for confidentiality reasons, as the number of Other Medical Practitioners in some electoral divisions is small.

Statistical Notes

These statistics relate to all providers of at least one service on a âfee-for-serviceâ basis and for which Medicare benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in the years in question. Excluded are details of services to public patients in hospital, to Department of Veteransâ Affairs patients and some compensation cases.

The simple headcounts given above do not account for differences in the number of services claimed and will include a high proportion of casual and part-time practitioners. Therefore it will not accurately represent the supply of doctors.

It is for this reason that Full-Time Equivalent (FTE) practitioner is the statistic used in the population ratios given above. FTE is a standardised measure to estimate the number of full-time doctors which adjusts for the partial contribution of casual and part-time doctors. FTE is calculated by dividing each doctorâs Medicare billing by the average billing of full-time doctors for the reference period. Where the doctorâs Medicare billing is greater than or equal to the mean billing of full-time doctors, then the FTE is capped at one.
In general terms, General Practitioners are those practitioners with at least 50% of Schedule fee income from non-referred (GP) attendances in the June quarter of the years in question.

These statistics were compiled from Medicare data on the basis of servicing provider postcode. In compiling statistics for federal electoral division boundaries, statistics by servicing provider postcode were mapped to electorate according to the proportion of the population of each postcode in each federal electoral division.
State-level statistics were compiled by allocating each postcode to a single state only. National statistics are the aggregate of all providers.

Electorate information is based on boundaries for the 2004 Commonwealth Electorate Divisions (CED) and, where possible, the Estimated Resident Population (ERP) for each CED as at June 30 for each year, as calculated by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). Significant changes to the CED boundaries and population occurred in a number of states. Data in this report should not be compared to previous data published at an electorate level which uses superseded CED boundaries and population figures. These figures can not be aggregated to state and national totals.
State and national information for each financial year is based on the mean ERP for each reference period and is derived from ABS Australian Demographic Statistics 3101.0 Table 4.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: Has Defence chartered any aircraft to meet the ADFâs requirements for a cargo service to the Middle East in support of the International Coalition against Terror; if so, in respect of each aircraft chartered since January 2003, what was (a) the date of the charter, (b) the cost of the charter, (c) the purpose of the charter, (d) the company from which the aircraft was chartered; and (e) the type of aircraft that was chartered.

Were any of the aircraft chartered in breach of any aircraft noise regulations applicable to any Australian or overseas jurisdictions; if so, what are the details of any waivers issued for breaches including an explanation of the reasons behind the granting of the waiver.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Yes, refer to Attachment A. (Note: For part (a) the invoice date has been provided. The dates of charter are not readily available, and Defence is not able to devote the considerable time and resources required to collect and assemble the information).

No. To avoid any breach of aircraft noise regulations, a waiver was sought for the Ilyushin-76 and Antonov-124 aircraft, which was provided in accordance with Chapter 3 of the Department of Transport and Regional Service Air Navigation (Aircraft Noise) Regulations.
No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 23Â May 2005:

item.para: Is he aware that in 2004, as part of a product recall process involving swimming pool ionisers, the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) required that suppliers direct their existing clients to use chlorine in conjunction with silver and copper ionisers in their swimming pools.

Did the APVMA subsequently change its directive to the industry instructing suppliers to convey to their clients that the APVMA simply recommends the use of chlorine; if so, why did the APVMA do this.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes. Throughout the recall process, the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) required suppliers of unregistered ionisers to include instructions to pool owners to use the ioniser system in conjunction with chlorine. Based on the information before it, the APVMA considered this necessary to ensure adequate sanitation of the pools to protect users from human pathogens.

Yes. The Commonwealth Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) directed the APVMA to issue the permits that recommend the use of chlorine. That direction was in respect of two particular ioniser systems, a component of which is a peroxygen oxidiser. The AAT considered that there was limited evidence that the copper/silver ions together with this peroxygen oxidiser might have some degree of sanitising effect. Only a few ioniser systems on the market rely upon this combination of chemicals.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 23Â May 2005:

item.para: Who is on the (a) board of management of the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) and (b) APVMAâs technical committees.
What prerequisites does a candidate need to meet to be selected to sit on (a) the management board and (b) a technical committee.
Do any particular qualifications disqualify a candidate from sitting on (a) the board of management and (b) a technical committee.
Do any members of the (a) board of management and (b) technical committees have a background in the chemical industry.

Is he aware that Senator Richard Colbeck gave an undertaking in a letter to a Queensland resident on 31 March 2005 that he would institute an independent review of the APVMAâs performance in the near future.

item.para: The APVMA has a number of stakeholder consultative committees. These are not decision-making committees, but provide a forum for liaison between the APVMA and its various stakeholder groups â the community and rural organisations, the industry, and State/Commonwealth agencies involved in the National Registration Scheme. Its key industry consultative committee is the Industry Liaison Committee (ILC), a technical sub-group of which is the Industry Technical Committee (ITC). The key purpose of the ILC/ITC is to provide a forum for consultation between the APVMA and peak industry bodies â it does not make regulatory decisions. The following industry associations are represented â Avcare Ltd, Aerosol Association of Australia Ltd, ACCORD Australasia Ltd, Nursery and Garden Industry Association, Pet Industry Association of Australia Ltd, Plastics and Chemicals Industries Association, Swimming Pool and Spa Association of Australia, Veterinary Manufacturers and Distributors Association, and Generic Agricultural Chemical Association.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, in writing, on 25 May 2005:

item.para: Is the Minister aware of the Commonwealth Governmentâs commitment to double the number of exporters by the year 2006.
By what means and by which agency, organisation or group is data to be collected to measure performance against this target.
What is the base figure against which success will be measured and from which year was the base figure chosen.
In the year (a) 2002, (b) 2003, and (c) 2004 how many exporters were counted for the purpose of comparison against the target.
What other initiatives does the Commonwealth intend to introduce to assist in meeting the target and from when will they be available.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The Doubling Strategy was announced as a whole of government initiative following the 2001 election.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics releases figures of the number of exporters in December each year for the previous fiscal year.
The base figure is 25,000 exporters from fiscal year 2000/01.

ABS data shows a 23% increase in the number of exporters from a base of approximately 25,000 in 2000/01 to the last reported figures for 2003/04. In 2001/02 there were 31,450 exporters, in 2002/03 there were 31,174 exporters and in 2003/04 there were 30,788 exporters.
Austrade proposes a number of different initiatives aimed at identifying and assisting potential exporters to achieve sustainable international success including:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Implementation of the Export Hubs, a program funded by the Government to co-locate the services of AusIndustry and Austrade in eight regional locations, specifically to provide Australian businesses with easier access to government assistance in the development of their businesses and the passage into export. Most of the Export Hubs are due to be opened between June and August 2005.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Ongoing administration of the Export Market Development Scheme to which the Government has provided $30 million of additional funding in 2004/05 and the subsequent two years.

No.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 25 May 2005:

quote.para: Further to the answer to question No. 214 (Hansard, 10 May 2005, page 87), will the ABC Board and management introduce a contemporary music mainstream ABC FM station to cater for the vast majority of people who neither enjoy youth rock music nor classical music; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

quote.para: The ABC has provided the following advice:

ABC Radio has three music services - ABC Classic FM; triple j; and dig (the ABCâs first internet radio service) â each deliberately designed to have a distinct approach and genre focus. At the time of their establishment, each of these music services created a new offering within the radio market.

dig, the ABCâs first internet radio station, launched in July 2002, was established because ABC Radio recognised there was a considerable segment of the radio audience not well served - people over 30 who want an interesting, eclectic and alternative mix of music that they cannot get from existing radio services, either ABC, commercial or community stations on a consistent basis.
The ABC is keen to explore opportunities to provide services to meet the needs of audiences that are not adequately served by existing national or commercial stations.

While the ABC would prefer dig to be available as an FM network, there is a shortage of FM frequencies. There is no FM spectrum available in the major capital cities and other large centres. Consequently, the ABC is focusing on digital radio and the potential for new services.

dig offers a stream of diverse music, the latest in music news, audio features on demand including reviews, concerts and interviews and engaging interactive content. Two new music streams have been added to the original service: digJAZZ (from November 2004) and digCOUNTRY (from January 2005).
dig is also broadcast on the digital television spectrum [channel 200] as an audio service and is now also available on the subscription television platform through Foxtel and Austar.

Since the end of 2003, the ABC has been participating in digital radio trials in Sydney and Melbourne conducted by Digital Radio Broadcasting Australia - a consortium of Commercial Radio Australia, the ABC and SBS â and Broadcast Australia respectively.
dig and ABC Classic FM are broadcast in the trials in both cities, and ABC NewsRadio/PNN is broadcast in Melbourne.
The Digital Radio Broadcasting Australia consortium is also considering further trials in regional centres.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: Have any changes been made to the regulation of the trade in live sheep in the past 2 years; and if so what were they?
Are there any changes to the regulations anticipated or planned in the future?

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: To give effect to the governmentâs response to the Keniry Report recommendations, changes to the Export Control Act 1982, Export Control (Animals) Order 2004, Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Act 1997 (âthe AMLI Actâ) and Australian Meat and Live-stock (Export Licensing) Regulations 1998 (âthe Regulationsâ) commenced on 1 December 2005.

The changes to the AMLI Act and the Regulations place the responsibility for issuing export licences to livestock exporters with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS). The amendments include a reference to the Australian Standards for the Export of Livestock (ASEL). Exporters must demonstrate their capacity to comply with the ASEL before being granted an export licence.
AQIS has amended the Regulations to allow the Australian Standards for the Export of Livestock (ASEL) to be updated through an AMLI Order.

The changes in the Export Control Act 1982 and Export Control (Animals) OrderÂ 2004 (âthe Orderâ) have changed the regulations for and the process of preparing a consignment of livestock for export including consignment risk management planning, the use of accredited veterinarians and the use of registered premises.

The Order has been amended to allow updated registration details of AQIS accredited veterinarians. A further amendment to the Order is being drafted that will require veterinarians to complete a prescribed training course before gaining accreditation.
Changes to the Export Control (Fees) Orders 2001 commenced 1 July 2004. The amendments allow for cost recovery of AQIS inspection and certification services.

AQIS proposes to amend the Order to streamline the process for exports of livestock by airfreight as the animal welfare risks associated with airfreight consignments are lower than the risks associated with sea transport.
AQIS will formulate AMLI Orders to update the version of ASEL as necessary.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What sum was spent on the AusAID project to train 1,718 Chinese officials in support of Chinaâs application for accession to the World Trade Organisation?
Was the training contracted out; if so, which company or companies carried out this work on behalf of AusAID and what is its postal address?
Which other firms tendered for this work and what are their postal addresses?
Where did the training take place?

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr Truss

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian expenditure on the project totalled A$7.6 million.
The project was contracted out to a consortium of Hassall & Associates (HAI) and IDP Education Australia (IDP).
The postal addresses are:
Hassall & Associates International
GPO Box 1877 Canberra ACT 2600
IDP Education Australia
GPO Box 2006 Canberra ACT 2601
There were three tenders for the project:
I. Hassall and Associates Pty Ltd in association with IDP Education Australia (successful tender â addresses above).
II. RMIT International Pty Ltd
GPO Box 2476V Melbourne Victoria 3001
III. Overseas Projects Corporation of Victoria Ltd (OPCV Ltd) in association with Monash Mount Eliza Business School (now the Mt Eliza Centre For Executive Education).

On 2 July 2004, the Victorian Minister for State and Regional Development, John Brumby, announced the sale of OPCV Ltd to the global professional services consultancy company, Sinclair Knight Merz (SKM). The Melbourne office of SKM is located at the following address:
Sinclair Knight Merz
590 Orrong Road Armadale Melbourne Victoria 3143
Address for the Mt Eliza Centre for Executive Education:
Mt Eliza Centre For Executive Education
Kunyung Road Mt Eliza Victoria 3930

The training took place both in China and Australia. It included workshops in a number of Chinese cities, including Beijing, Shanghai, Qingdao, Kunming, Suzhou and Beideha; programs at the University of Adelaide and at Curtin University in Perth; and study visits to a number of Australian cities including Sydney, Canberra, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract titled âLocal Sustainability Programâ between AusAID and ACIL Australia Pty Ltd in the Philippines?
Was this contract pursuant to a competitive tender process?
What goods and services were provided by the contractor?
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract?

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The total value of the contract was $11,999,168.83
Yes

The goal of the Philippines-Australia Local Sustainability Program was to strengthen participatory planning processes and local management of resources for the promotion of sustainable community livelihoods within the province of Misamis Occidental (Region IX, Mindanao). The contractor provided the following services:
-Â Â Â Â Â Â community and Local Government Unit (LGU) activities for strengthened resource planning and management;
-Â Â Â Â Â Â development facility activities to fund a range of community and LGU projects; and
-Â Â Â Â Â Â program management.
Fixed Fees, which included Payment Milestones and Personnel Costs, were set at a maximum value of $3,266,276.83
Procurement was set at a maximum value of $186,747.00

The Program Development Facility, which covered costs related to the community and local government activities and was held in a separate Trust Account managed by the Contractor, was reimbursable to a maximum of $8,404,000.00
Other reimbursable costs were set at a maximum of $142,145.00.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract titled âFull Level Funding for TEARâ between AusAID and Tear Australia Inc.
Was this contract awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process.
What goods and services were provided by the contractor.
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: AusAID does not currently hold a contract with TEAR Australia Inc entitled âFull Level Funding for TEARâ. However, TEAR does have a five year umbrella contract with AusAID entitled âPeriodic Fundingâ. Funding is provided annually under this umbrella contract in accordance with individual service orders/exchanges of letters and is subject to the maintenance of accreditation with AusAID. The value of funding under the umbrella contract in Financial Year 2004/05 was $788,066.

The umbrella contract between AusAID and TEAR Australia Inc was not awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process. However, to be awarded an umbrella contract TEAR Australia Inc had to be accredited with AusAID. To be accredited TEAR Australia Inc has undergone a rigorous assessment process focusing on agency accountability and risk management.

There are no goods and services specified in the umbrella contract for âPeriodic Fundingâ. Accreditation provides NGOs with access to annually appropriated funding under the AusAID NGO Cooperation Program, which is a matching funding program to extend NGOs own development programs.
A breakdown of costs is not specified in the umbrella contract for Periodic Funding.

subdebateinfo.title: AusAID Pest Management in the Pacific Project

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract titled âPest Management in the Pacific Projectâ between AusAID and the Secretariat of the Pacific Community.
Was this contract awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process.
What goods and services were provided by the contractor.
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The total value of expenditure on the contract was $A1,608,883.
No. AusAID agreed to co-fund the project proposed by the Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC).
The goods and services provided by SPC included technical assistance, equipment and training.

Several donors contributed funding for this SPC project. Expenditure was divided between five components: Fruit fly management; Plant protection Micronesia; Information and extension services; Plant protection in Cook Islands, Niue and Tokelau; and Project management. The SPC was not required to attribute expenditure to the donors either by component or by the goods and services listed in question three. The contributions of the donors were:
Australia: $A 1.6 million through AusAID;
New Zealand: $NZ 1.8 million; and
United Nations Development Program: $US 100,000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract titled âAustralian Youth Ambassadors for Development Programâ between AusAID and Austraining International Pty Ltd?
Was this contract awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process?
What goods and services were provided by the contractor?
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract?

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The total value of the contract titled âAustralian Youth Ambassadors for Development Programâ is A$30,495,475.
Yes.

The contractor is providing a coordinated management service responsible for the delivery of all aspects of the Australian Youth Ambassadors for Development Program. This includes: identifying development related Youth Ambassadors assignments; placing around 250 skilled young Australians annually in 20 partner countries in the Asia-Pacific region; developing partnerships with Australian organisations; selecting recruiting and training Youth Ambassadors for overseas placement; managing in-country services; managing welfare, support and security of Youth Ambassadors overseas and managing provision of promotion, public relations, marketing and a Youth Ambassador alumni network.

The breakdown of costs associated with the contract is A$6,410,238 Fixed Management Fees (Milestone Payments), A$5,704,520 Reimbursable Costs and A$18,380,717 Imprest Account (Youth Ambassador allowance payments).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract titled âAustralian Youth Ambassadors for Development Program â Imprest Accountâ between AusAID and Austraining International Pty Ltd?
Was this contract awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process?
What goods and services were provided by the contractor?
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract?

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The Imprest Account component of the contract titled âAustralian Youth Ambassadors for Development Programâ is A$18,380,717. The total value of the contract is A$30,495,475. (See also answer to QON 1521)
Yes.
The Imprest Account component covers all Youth Ambassadors allowance payments. (See also answer to QON 1521 for full detail)
(4)Â Â (See answer to QON 1521)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contracts titled âBase Level Agencyâ between AusAID and Simaid.
Were these contracts awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process.
What goods and services were provided by the contractor.
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contracts.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: AusAID does not currently hold a contract with the Sudan Interior Mission Aid Fund (SIMAID) entitled âBase Level Agencyâ. However, SIMAID does have a five year umbrella contract with AusAID entitled âPeriodic Fundingâ. Funding is provided annually under this umbrella contract in accordance with individual service orders/exchanges of letters and is subject to the maintenance of accreditation with AusAID. There has been no allocation of funding to SIMAID in Financial Year 2004/05.

The umbrella contract between AusAID and SIMAID was not awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process. However, to be awarded an umbrella contract SIMAID had to be accredited with AusAID. To be accredited with AusAID SIMAID had to go through a rigorous process focusing on agency accountability and risk management. SIMAID withdrew from the accreditation process in 2004 and is no longer accredited with AusAID.
There are no goods and services specified in the umbrella contract for Periodic Funding.
A breakdown of costs is not specified in the umbrella contract for Periodic Funding.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract titled âProvision of Client Services â G Smithâ between AusAID and Ambit Group Pty Ltd.
Was this contract awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process.
What goods and services were provided by the contractor.
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The total value of the contract as gazetted was $276,137.40 (exclusive of GST).
Yes.
The services provided by the contractor were to:
ââ¦ provide Mr Greg Smith (the âConsultantâ) or such other person as a consultant who is acceptable to AusAID to undertake the full-time duties of Client Services Support in AusAID House.â
In this role, Mr Smith provided first level support on AusAIDâs Information Technology Section Help Desk.
The breakdown of actual costs associated with the contract included the provision of services only, at a total of $226,846.14 (exclusive of GST).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract titled âProvision of Communication Specialist Support â GÂ Krinasâ between AusAID and Frontier Group Australia Pty Ltd.
Was this contract awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process.
What goods and services were provided by the contractor.
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The total value of the contract, as gazetted, was $445,000.00 (exclusive of GST).
Yes.
The services provided by the contractor were to:
ââ¦ provide Mr George Krinas (the âConsultantâ) or such other person as a consultant who is acceptable to AusAID to undertake the full-time duties of a Senior Communication Specialist.

The Consultant is responsible to provide direction, high-level technical support and administration of the AusAID LAN/WAN communications infrastructure. In addition, as part of the Network and Communications (Netcomms) Team, provide development and maintenance support for the Network operating system; assist in networking issues relating to storage; and assist with the development and maintenance of the desktop environment.â
The breakdown of actual costs associated with the contract included the provision of services only, at a total of $418,236 (exclusive of GST).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 25 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract titled Diesel Generator/Waste Heat Boilersâ between AusAID and Sinclair Knight Merz Pty Ltd.
Was this contract awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process.
What goods and services were provided by the contractor.
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The total value of the contract was $3,600,850.40.
The contract was awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process.

Under the terms of the contract Sinclair Knight Merz was tasked with the procurement and installation of two diesel generators, three waste heat boilers and associated equipment for the Nauru Power Plant on behalf of AusAID. SKM provided the following:
Selection, procurement and shipping of diesel generators, waste heat boilers and associated equipment.
Construction supervision, commissioning and testing of newly installed plant and equipment.
Breakdown of costs associated with the contract are as follows:
Generators, waste heat boilers and associated equipment: $3,159,761.82
Procurement fees: $159,921.62
Personnel Services:$270, 995.07
Total expenditure: $3,590,678.51

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 25 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract titled âNauru Airport Facilities Rectification Worksâ awarded by AusAID to Airways Consulting Services NZ.
Was this contract awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process.
What goods and services were provided by the contractor.
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The total value of the contract was $218,600.
The contract was awarded pursuant to a competitive process.

Airways Consulting Services NZ was tasked, on behalf of AusAID, with rectifying the deficiencies noted in the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) audit of Nauru Airport in August 2001. Airways Consulting Services NZ provided the following:
Batteries for Very High Frequency Omnidirectional Range (VOR) and Distance Measuring Equipment (DME).
Power and communication cables.
Generators for 15kva and 22kva loads.
Navaid Alarm display/driver.
Radio management system.
8 Channel voice recorder.
121.5Mhz transmitter/receiver.
Professional advice to the Government of Nauru on the installation, maintenance and use of the above equipment.
Breakdown of costs associated with the contract is as follows:
Equipment as above: $149,139.16
Professional fees: $40,213.00
Total expenditure: $189,352.16

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract titled âProvision of Consultancy Services Associated with the Implementation of AusAIDâs Strategic Planâ between AusAID and Executive Coach Pty Ltd.
Was this contract awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process.
What goods and services were provided by the contractor.
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The total value of the contract was $140,722 plus GST.

No. Consistent with Finance Management Act Regulation 8, the delegate agreed that given the nature of the task and the time required the selection was a cost effective solution for the agency. The Contract provided no guarantee of work.
The contractor was contracted to provide the following services:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Executive coaching services to individual managers;

item.label: (b)
item.para: Consulting services and advice regarding implementation of work unit activities to promote organisational/cultural hange consistent with the Strategic Plan; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: Provision of advice regarding leadership/management issues.
The breakdown of costs associated with the contract is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Executive coaching services: 32% of cost of the contract;

item.label: (b)
item.para: Consulting services: 24% of cost of the contract; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: Leadership/management development: 44% of the contract.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract titled âProvision of photocopying and associated services for AusAID central office, Canberraâ between AusAID and Mabuhay Investment Pty Ltd.
Was this contract awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process.
What goods and services were provided by the contractor.
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The amount payable by AusAID to the Contractor including any option period shall not exceed the sum of $440,000 plus GST. The initial term of the contract was 1 July 2002 to 30 June 2003. The contract allowed for AusAID to use options to extend the period beyond the initial term. The contract was extended to 30 June 2007. Mahuby Investments Pty Ltd advised AusAID that they went into voluntary administration on 15/9/04. AusAID terminated the contract on 15/9/04.
The contract was awarded under a restricted tender process (five potential tenderers where approached). The successful tenderer was notified on the Internet via AusTender.
The tender requested the provision of AusAID Central Office high volume and specialised photocopying services.
Expenditure under the contract was $96,666 in 2002/03; $44,700 in 2003/04 and $7,900 in 2004/05. The small amount in 04/05 is due to Mahuby Investments going into voluntary administration on 15/9/04.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: What was the total value of the contract entitled âEssential Media Communicationsâ between AusAID and Essential media Communications Pty Ltd.
Was this contract awarded pursuant to a competitive tender process.
What goods and services were provided by the contractor.
What is the breakdown of costs associated with the contract.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs questions is as follows:

item.para: The total value of the contract was not to exceed a fixed amount of $145,500.00 plus GST of $14,550.00.
Yes.

The Services provided by the contractor were the design, management and coordination of two Stakeholder Seminars, one on HIV/AIDS held in Cairns in October 2003 and one on trade and development in Sydney in November 2003. These services included:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Strategic planning and project preparation to ensure effective implementation;

item.label: (b)
item.para: All aspects of event management and implementation;

item.label: (c)
item.para: Design and production of all printed materials and promotional signage including researching and writing copy and

item.label: (d)
item.para: Development and implementation of a media strategy for each event.
A total of $92,284.24 was expended.

item.label: (a)
item.para: $70,984.00 was paid in management fees.

item.label: (b)
item.para: $21,300.24 was paid in reimbursable expenses.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: How many (a) before-school care, (b) after-school care, (c) vacation care, (d) long day care and (e) family day care places exist in the electoral division of Griffith.
How many children are on waiting lists for a place in (a) before-school care, (b) after-school care, (c) vacation care (d) long day care and (e) family day care in the electoral division of Griffith.

What is the average waiting time for in terms of providers meeting in full the childcare requests of parents in (a) before-school care, (b) after-school care, (c) vacation care, (d) long day care and (e) family day care in the electoral division of Griffith.
What is the average time a child in the electoral division of Griffith is on a waiting list for a childcare place.
How many children are on waiting lists for a place in (a) before-school care, (b) after-school care, (c) vacation care, (d) long day care and (e) family day care in (i) Queensland.
What sum does the Commonwealth spend on (a) before-school care, (b) after-school care, (c) vacation care, (d) long day care and (e) family day care in the electoral division of Griffith.
What are the names and contact details of all members of the Queensland Child Care Planning Advisory Committee (QCCPAC).
What was the date of the meeting of the QCCPAC.
What were the 60 âcommunities of interestâ that the QCCPAC identified as areas of high need.
What recommendations did the QCCPAC make to the Department for further services in the âcommunities of interestâ following their assessment.
