item.para: Since 2001, Centrelink has been combining co-located and co-managed After School and Before School Hours Care services as a single administered Outside School Hours Care service.

As at September 2004, there were: (a)(b) 2,225 approved places for outside school hours care; (c) 1,142 approved places for vacation care; (d) 2,291 approved places for long day care; and (e) 358 approved places for family day care in the electoral division of Griffith (Source: Centrelink administrative data).
The Department monitors expressions of interest for outside school hours places and family day care. The Australian Government does not allocate long day care places.
See answer to (2) above.
See answer to (2) above.
See answer to (2) above.

During the 2003-04 financial year the Commonwealth spent (a) (b) $39,293 on outside school hours care, (c) $20,816 on vacation care, (d) $154,777 on long day care and (e) $381,211 on family day care in the electoral division of Griffith. (Source: FaCS Queensland State Office and Centrelink administrative data). These amounts exclude Child Care Benefit paid to assist parents of children in approved child care services and also excludes the child care tax rebate.

28 April 2004.

Not all these planning areas were identified as needing additional places (see answer to 10 below).

At its last meeting, the Queensland Planning Advisory Committee endorsed criteria for allocating both outside school hours care and family day care places on the basis of relative need and recommended the Department continue allocating places in accordance with the criteria.
No. I am advised that the case referred to does not relate to an approved child care service, but to a Queensland Government-funded preschool that opened its 2008 waiting list for registrations.

item.para: Student organisations are not trade unions because their student members are not employees of universities. However student organisations may undertake some similar activities including advocacy on behalf of students and representation of students.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 31 May 2005:

item.para: Who represented Australia at the OECD meeting in Paris on 3-4 May 2005.

Did the Australian Government representatives support the commitment to significantly increase the volume of aid to assist in meeting the Millennium Development Goals by 2015 as included in the communique from the meeting; if so, what action does the Government propose to take to implement this commitment.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Please see the Minister for Foreign Affairsâ answer to question 1650.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade and the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 31 May 2005:

item.para: Who represented Australia at the OECD meeting in Paris on 3-4 May 2005.

Did the Australian Government representatives support the commitment to significantly increase the volume of aid to assist in meeting the Millennium Development Goals by 2015 as included in the communiquÃ© from the meeting; if so, what action does the Government propose to take to implement this commitment.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of myself and the Minister for Trade, the answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The Minister for Trade, the Hon Mark Vaile MP, represented Australia at the OECD Ministerial Council Meeting on 3-4 May 2005.

The OECD Ministerial Council Meeting issued a Chairâs Summary, OECD Statement to the Follow-up of the UN Millennium Declaration and Monterrey Consensus, in lieu of a communiquÃ©. The OECD Statement is consistent with the Monterrey Consensus and the UN Millennium Declaration which Australia supports. This Statement reaffirms the importance of resources and the need to use aid more effectively, including the importance of stable and predictable financial flows, the need for policy coherence, the importance of dialogue and a well-functioning multilateral system, and the need for the OECD to strengthen its partnership with developing countries and other international organisations.

Australia supports the UN target of 0.7 per cent ratio of Official Development Assistance to Gross National Income (ODA/GNI). The Australian Government endeavours to maintain our ODA at the highest level consistent with the needs of partner countries, Australiaâs capacity to assist and other priorities for Australian Government expenditure.

In 2005-06, the Australian Government will provide an estimated $2.491 billion in ODA. This is an increase of $358 million - almost 12 per cent - over the 2004-05 budget figure and a real increase of 5.8 per cent over the 2004-05 expected outcome of $2.235 billion. This represents the fifth successive annual increase in the real value of Australiaâs ODA, and brings Australiaâs ODA in 2005-06 to an estimated 24 per cent greater in real terms than was provided in 1995-96. Australiaâs ODA/GNI ratio for 2005-06 is estimated at 0.28 per cent, placing Australia above the latest available weighted OECD Development Assistance Committee donor average of 0.25 per cent for 2004.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 1 June 2005:

quote.para: Will the offices of any Australian Industrial Relations Commissioners be terminated as a result of the reduction in the workload of the Commission.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr Andrews

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: It is the President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC), not the Government, that manages the resources of the AIRC in order to ensure that the AIRC can provide its services to the community in an effective manner.

That being said, it should not be automatically assumed that the Governmentâs proposed reforms will reduce the overall workload of the AIRC. As I have indicated previously, an assessment of the net impact on the workload of the AIRC is unlikely to be made until the Governmentâs reforms have been in effect for a period of 6 to 12 months.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 14 June 2005:

item.para: In respect of the Ministerâs foreword to the Settlement Grants Program Discussion Paper 2005 which states âThese recommendations were endorsed by Cabinet, and the Government is committed to their implementationâ, what role will written and oral submissions play in any further development of the policy.

Does the statement in the discussion paper that the provision of information will continue to be funded, mean that (a) Migrant Resource Centres (MRCs) will be able to provide DIMIA forms to clients and (b) MRC staff will be able to assist clients to access the DIMIA website or other online services on the MRC premises; if not, what other provisions is the Government making for clients who require these services.

Does the Minister expect, and will the Government provide for, a significant increase in the number of approaches to Federal Members of Parliament on immigration matters if restrictions on funding for the provision of immigration-related services are enacted.

Can the Minister say which bodies will be able to initiate and participate in multicultural events and festivals whose purpose is to improve the social environment for newly arrived communities when such activities are no longer funded by the Government.
What quality assurance mechanisms will be put in place to ensure the accuracy of settlement needs data to the department.

Can the Minister explain how migrants in regional and rural areas will be able to access migration advice and translation services when the MRCs are not funded to provide these services, especially in areas where other providers of these services do not exist or are difficult to access.

In respect of the suggestion in the discussion paper that the provision of migration advice might be replaced by other funding programs such as the Immigration Advice and Application Assistance Scheme, can the Minister explain how clients seeking to apply for visas to enable family members to join them in Australia will access assistance when the Immigration Advice and Application Assistance Scheme is available to the direct applicant only and does not assist with the sponsorship of family members under the special humanitarian program.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The Settlement Grants Program Discussion Paper was released on 6 April 2005 to generate input on the implementation of the new Settlement Grants Program. Community consultations were held in all capital cities in April and May and written submissions were accepted until the end of May 2005.
Input from the consultations and written submissions will inform the further development of the new program, with a final policy paper to be released in August 2005.

(2)Â Â (3) (6) and (7) The issue of funding of migration advice and information was raised at the community consultations and featured in a number of written submissions. I will give the matter careful consideration when deciding on the final parameters of the new program.

(6) and (7) The issue of funding of migration advice and information was raised at the community consultations and featured in a number of written submissions. I will give the matter careful consideration when deciding on the final parameters of the new program.

Settlement Programs currently administered by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs do not fund multicultural events or festivals. The new Settlement Grants Program is consistent with current policy.

A variety of stakeholders will have input into the settlement needs-based planning process on an annual basis to identify settlement priorities for the region. Settlement priorities for the first round of the new Settlement Grants Program will be made public, and inform the advertising of the grants program, in October 2005.

Making public the priority needs in this manner on an annual basis will make the needs-identification and grants application process more consultative and transparent for the settlement services sector. The annual needs assessment will ensure regular input from the sector and other service agencies to identify changing settlement patterns and needs.
Performance indicators will be measured by client outcomes from settlement services measured through program evaluations and surveys and advice from relevant government agencies.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 14 June 2005:

quote.para: What is his response to the statement by Mr Ian Spring published in Infrastructure Australia, MayÂ 2005, that âAustralia has almost no national debt. We also have awful infrastructure. These two things are connected. While we have followed zero-debt policies, other countries have borrowed and built and have the infrastructure to show for it.â

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Since 1996-97, this Government has been responsible for the repayment of around $90 billion of debt, strengthening the Governmentâs financial position and contributing to the strong performance of the Australian economy. The interest saving from not having to service that debt is around $5.7Â billion every year; money that can now be used in important areas like health, education, national security and infrastructure.

Maintaining low debt and good management of the Budget have allowed the Government to invest significantly in infrastructure. InÂ JuneÂ 2004, the Government announced its strategic longâterm land transport policy, AusLink, a massive investment in Australiaâs road and rail infrastructure. Under AusLink, the Australian Government will spend $12 billion on land transport infrastructure between 2004-05 and 2008-09. However, the vast majority of responsibility for infrastructure lies with the state and territory governments, who are financially well placed to deal with infrastructure needs. In 2005â06, the Australian Government will provide an estimated $64.8Â billion to the states and territories, including GST revenue.

In March 2005, the Government established an infrastructure taskforce to identify any bottlenecks of a physical or regulatory kind in the operation of Australiaâs infrastructure which may impede the full realisation of our export opportunities. The Taskforce found there were localised capacity constraints, particularly for coal export infrastructure, but that there was no infrastructure crisis. At its meeting on 3Â June 2005, the Council of Australian Governments agreed with this conclusion.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 14 June 2005:

item.para: Further to the answer to question No. 727 (Hansard, 23 May 2005, page 141), does a schoolâs Socio-Economic Status (SES) score represent an average socioeconomic profile of the districts from which that schoolâs students are drawn; if not, why not.

Do students drawn from wealthier families in a poor district contribute to their school being awarded a lower SES score and hence a higher recurrent grant than if the score were based on their own familyâs circumstances; if not, why not.
Is the SES methodology a potentially misleading indicator of a schoolâs educational need; if not, why not.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes. A schoolâs socio-economic status (SES) score represents an average socio-economic profile of the census collection districts from which that non-government schoolâs students are drawn.

A non-government schoolâs SES score is calculated using the average socio-economic profile of the census collection districts from which that schoolâs students are drawn. The SES model does not measure the wealth of any individual family. Both high and low income families contribute to the SES scores of the census collection districts in which they reside. The SES model ranks each school relative to other schools based on the SES of each schoolâs community.

The specific objective for the General Recurrent Grants Programme is to help non-government schools with the recurrent costs of school education so that they can offer students educational programmes directed towards the achievement of the Australian Governmentâs priorities for schooling.

The level of General Recurrent Funding provided to a non-government school is based on the schoolâs SES score. The SES index that is used to calculate a non-government schoolâs SES score measures the income, education and occupation levels of all residents within the census collection districts from which a school draws its students. The SES approach ranks non-government school communities relative to each other and is based on Australian Bureau of Statistics Census data that are consistent for all schools.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 15 June 2005:

item.para: Is he able to say whether charges have been laid against Ching Cheong, the Hong Kong journalist, who was arrested 16 years ago reportedly for resigning his position in protest over the massacre in Tiananmen Square; if so, what are they.
Is the Government monitoring the cases of journalists, such as Ching Cheong and Shi Tao, gaoled in relation to their views about the Tiananmen Square massacre.
Is he able to say whether the Chinese Government intends to prosecute these journalists or release them from detention.
Has the Government raised, in the context of the Australia-China human rights dialogue, the cases of the estimated 42 journalists in gaol in China; if not, why not.
Has the Government made any representations to Chinese authorities about the detention of journalists; if not, why not.
What steps has the Government taken to promote freedom of speech and freedom of the press in China.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: According to Chinese public security authorities, Ching Cheong has been detained in China while authorities investigate allegations that he was spying for an unnamed overseas intelligence organisation.
Yes.
Do not know at this stage what the Chinese government intends to do.
The government has raised individual cases of Chinese journalists in detention at the Human Rights Dialogue.
Yes.
The government has raised issues of freedom of speech and freedom of the press at the Human Rights Dialogue. These issues have also been raised during Embassy representations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 15 June 2005:

item.para: Is he able to confirm reports in the New York Times and on the AP wires that Syria fired three Scud missiles on 27 May 2005, one of which broke up over Turkey.
Is the Government taking any action in response to Syriaâs ability to undertake chemical attacks against civilian targets in neighbouring countries.
What is the Governmentâs response to Amnesty International reports that an Islamic Cleric, Sheikh Muhammad Maâshuq al-Khiznawi, was tortured to death by Syrian Military Intelligence.
Has the Government made any representations about the serious human rights violations in Syria generally and about the Sheikh Muhammad Maâshuq al-Khiznawi case in particular; if not, why not.
What steps has the Government taken to encourage the Syrian Government improve its human rights record.
Has the Government made any comment about the Sheikh Muhammad Maâshuq al-Khiznawi case to the Syrian Embassy in Canberra.
What role does bilateral trade play in influencing the Australian Governmentâs policy on actions to promote human rights in Syria.
How recently did the Syrian Embassy reopen in Canberra.
How does the Government reconcile Australiaâs expanded bilateral relationship with Syria with Australiaâs condemnation of Syriaâs role in promoting the Iraqi insurgency.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: I am aware of the media reports. The Government is not in a position to provide further information.

Australia actively encourages all countries that have not yet done so to sign and ratify the Chemical Weapons Convention, including Syria, and works through its chairmanship of the Australia Group to promote measures for preventing the proliferation of materials and equipment suitable for the development of chemical and biological weapons.

The Government is concerned about the circumstances surrounding the death of Sheikh al-Khiznawi, including allegations from Amnesty International and others that he died while in custody as a result of torture.

The Government has registered, through the Australian Embassy in Cairo which has non-resident accreditation to Syria, our concerns regarding the human rights situation in Syria, including the death of Sheikh al-Khiznawi and interference by the Syrian government in the functioning of non-government human rights organisations and the intimidation and arbitrary arrest and detention of their members.
The Government has taken appropriate opportunities, through the Australian Ambassador accredited to Syria (resident in Cairo), to make representations to the Syrian Government on human rights issues.
Our representations to the Syrian Government on the case of Sheikh al-Khiznawi have been made through the Australian Embassy in Cairo.
Bilateral trade does not influence the Governmentâs policy on actions to promote human rights in Syria.
The Syrian Embassy in Canberra opened on 25 February 2004.

We have and will continue to urge Syria to take stronger steps to cooperate in the war against terrorism and to improve control of its border with Iraq. Raising these and other issues of concern is not incompatible with the bilateral relationship we have with Syria.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, in writing, on 15 June 2005:

How recently did the Syrian Embassy reopen in Canberra.
How does the Government reconcile Australiaâs expanded bilateral relationship with Syria with Australiaâs condemnation of Syriaâs role in promoting the Iraqi insurgency.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Two-way merchandise trade between Australia and Syria amounted to A$14.5 million in the 2004 calendar year. Australiaâs merchandise exports to Syria were A$12.8 million while imports were A$1.7 million.
See answer to Question No 1699 (7).

(3)Â Â (a) Austrade has supported 13 Australian companies that have expressed interest in the Syrian market in the last financial year (2004/05). (b) We have no knowledge of Australian companies participating in or holding oil concessions in Syria.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: Austrade has supported 13 Australian companies that have expressed interest in the Syrian market in the last financial year (2004/05). (b) We have no knowledge of Australian companies participating in or holding oil concessions in Syria.
See answer to Question No 1699 (4).

We have and will continue to urge Syria to take stronger steps to cooperate in the war against terrorism and to improve control of its border with Iraq. Raising these and other issues of concern is not incompatible with the bilateral relationship we have with Syria.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 16 June 2005:

item.para: Has the Minister read the report titled âNew wave of refugeesâ in The Inner West Weekly on 9 June 2005 which reported that the State Director of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA), Mr Jim OâCallaghan, addressed the Ashfield Municipal Councilâs Local Government Multicultural Forum on Friday, 3 June 2005 and advised that âAfricans fleeing war-torn areas have replaced European and Middle Eastern migrants in Australiaâs refugee program creating new challenges for governments and communitiesâ.

Can the Minister confirm that (a) Ashfield Municipal Council made a written request to DIMIA for a financial contribution toward funding this forum in a letter dated 8 March 2005 and (b) DIMIA replied to Ashfield Municipal Council in a letter dated 1 June 2005 advising that the forum was not eligible for Commonwealth funding; if not, why not.
Why was the Ashfield Municipal Council Local Government Multicultural Forum ineligible for Commonwealth funding.
Will the Government provide financial and practical support for local governments working to promote tolerance and cultural harmony in Australia; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

(2)Â Â (a) Yes. (b) No. DIMIAâs response advised that while the forum would not be eligible for DIMIA funding generally, there are other ways in which local governments authorities may be eligible to apply for and receive financial support for multicultural projects.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: Yes. (b) No. DIMIAâs response advised that while the forum would not be eligible for DIMIA funding generally, there are other ways in which local governments authorities may be eligible to apply for and receive financial support for multicultural projects.
I am unable to respond concerning funding programs administered by other Commonwealth portfolios.

Yes. The Government has provided and will continue to provide both financial and practical support for local governments to promote tolerance and cultural harmony. Local government is one of the strategic focuses of the Australian Governmentâs key multicultural policy document, Multicultural Australia: United in Diversity â Strategic Directions for 2003 â 2006.

DIMIAâs Living in Harmony initiative funds projects aimed at promoting social cohesion and addressing racism and intolerance. Since 1999, 24 Living in Harmony grants have been awarded to local government authorities around Australia.

In 2000, Living in Harmony funding was also provided for a partnership with the Australian Local Government Association, together with Indigenous organisations, to promote the establishment of local symbols of reconciliation across Australia.

In early 2005, DIMIA sent a âhow toâ inter-faith kit to every local government authority in Australia on religious diversity, as a result of a project with the Australian Multicultural Foundation and the World Conference of Religions for Peace.

DIMIA sponsors a National Award for Local Government, administered by the Department of Transport and Regional Services, at a total cost of $60,500 over the last three years. This award focuses on and promotes community capacity building in the field of cultural diversity.

The Charter of Public Service in a Culturally Diverse Society guides government services and programs in responding appropriately to cultural diversity. It was endorsed by all levels of government in 1998.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, in writing, on 20 June 2005:

item.para: Can the Minister confirm that he has received correspondence from concerned parties regarding the proposed development of a large-scale abalone farm alongside the West Waldegrave Island Conservation Park.

Can the Minister confirm that these concerns relate to the fact that (a) this area hosts the fourth largest Australian Sea-lion colony which is listed as vulnerable by the World Conservation Union, (b) the proposed development involves the use of 15,000 square metres of netting less than 2 kilometres from the Australian Sea-lion Colony, and (c) this area is also visited by migrating Southern Right Whales and Humpback Whales which are both listed as threatened under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act.
Is the Minister aware that the CSIRO has noted that netting accounts for more sea-lion deaths than any other human activity.

Is the Minister prepared to invoke the provisions of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act to prevent the proposed abalone farm having a significant impact on the surrounding environment, in particular, on threatened species such as Southern Right Whales and Humpback Whales and the vulnerable Australian Sea-lion.
Can the Minister confirm that the overwhelming bulk of the Australian Sea-lion population live outside the Marine Mammal Protection Zone of the Great Australian Bight Marine Park.

What action will the Minister take to provide greater protection for the Australian Sea-lions, Southern Right Whales and Humpback Whales and fulfil the statement on the Department of Environment and Heritage website that the Marine Mammal Protection Zone of the Great Australian Bight Marine Park ââ¦is primarily intended to provide for undisturbed calving for the Southern Right Whale and protection of Australian Sea-lion coloniesâ.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr Truss

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Yes.
Yes.

I am not aware of the source of this particular statement. I am aware that interactions with fisheries, including aquaculture operations, can lead to fatal entanglement of Australian Sea-lions from time to time and that rates of Australian Sea-lion entanglement in discarded marine debris can be high.
My Department has contacted Australian Bight Aquaculture Ltd informing them of their responsibilities under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act).
Yes.

In February this year, I listed the Australian Sea-lion as vulnerable under the EPBC Act. As a consequence, activities that may have a significant impact on the Australian Sea-lion need my approval. Also, a draft recovery plan for the Australian Sea-lion is being prepared. A draft will be made available for public comment, identifying key threats to the species and outlining priority recovery actions.

Under the Marine Protected Areas Program I have provided funding for two projects to be conducted in the Great Australian Bight Marine Park (GABMP) to investigate the foraging behaviour and range of the Australian Sea-lion. This project will also document interactions between the Australian Sea-lion and marine industry.

The Marine Mammal Protection Zone of the GABMP was primarily set up to protect calving of the Southern Right Whale. Both the Southern Right Whale and the Humpback Whale have recovery plans in place and are given particular protection under the EPBC Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 21 June 2005:

item.para: Further to the answer to question No. 91 (Hansard, 8 February 2005, page 88), how many Australian born people of Maltese descent renounced their Australian citizenship after returning to Malta before the introduction of changes to citizenship law by the Maltese government in 2000.
When will the Government present the Australian Citizenship Legislation Amendment Bill to the Parliament.
Can he say what government priorities need to be taken into account before the introduction of the Australian Citizenship Legislation Amendment Bill.
Will the bill contain provisions to raise the age limit of 25 years for resumption of citizenship as presently provided for in section 23AB of the Citizenship Act.

Does the Government intend to resolve the discrepancy between Australian-born persons who acquired the citizenship of another country who can apply to resume Australian citizenship under 23AA of the Citizenship Act and those persons of Maltese descent who were compelled to renounce their Australian citizenship under Maltese law who are refused the right to resume Australian citizenship because they are over the age of 25.
Will the changes under the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill include children born to those persons whom the bill is intended to assist after the renunciation of their Australian citizenship.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Data is not available on the number of dual Australian/Maltese citizens who renounced their Australian citizenship prior to the introduction of changes to Maltaâs citizenship laws in 2000.
The draft legislation is expected to be available for introduction in the Parliament this year.
No.

and (5) As announced in July 2004, the proposed amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 include the removal of the age limit for the resumption of citizenship regardless of how a person ceased to be an Australian citizen.
Announcements were made in July 2004 on a number of proposed changes to citizenship legislation. Other matters remain under consideration.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm that the Liberal Member for Canning, Mr Randall, acted as an observer of the recent election in Lebanon; if so, in what capacity did Mr Randall travel to Lebanon (eg was he representing the Minister, the Government or the Parliament).
Were any costs associated with Mr Randallâs trip met by the Department of Foreign Affairs; if so, what costs were met and what was the sum involved.
Why was no member of the Opposition asked to act as an observer for the election in Lebanon.

Can he confirm that Government members also acted as observers at the recent election in (a) Iraq, (b) Zimbabwe, and (c) the Palestinian Territories; if so, why were no Opposition members asked to act as observers.
On what basis does he select Members or Senators to act as observers of foreign elections.
Can he explain how he can obtain a fair and objective assessment of elections in foreign countries when observer delegations have not included members of the Opposition.
Will he give an undertaking that in future when Members or Senators are asked to act as observers at foreign elections this will be done on a non-partisan basis.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Mr Randall acted as an official observer of the final round of the elections in Lebanon on 19 June as a representative of the Australia Government.
The costs of Mr Randallâs travel were met by the Department of Finance and Administration (DOFA) under Regulation 3C of the Parliamentary Entitlements Regulation 1997.
Mr Randall was nominated as a representative of the Government.

The Government sent official observers to the recent elections in Iraq (from Jordan), Mrs Joanna Gash MP, and the Palestinian Territories, Mr Phillip Barresi MP. The Government did not send an official observer to the elections in Zimbabwe in March; these were covered by our embassy in Harare. For the second part of the question, see (5) below.
Observers representing the Government are selected on the basis of a range of criteria, including their availability to travel and interest in observing a particular election.
Official Australian Government observers are expected to provide a fair and objective assessment of the election they are observing.
The Government will always send a well-qualified observer as its representative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: In respect of the construction of the Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (IRPC), what is the value of the main works phase of the Baulderstone Hornibrook contract.
What is the nature of the incentives in the contract for the use of local industry.
How many people from Christmas Island have been employed on the job and how many people from Christmas Island are undergoing apprenticeship training as part of the project.
What is the expected date of completion and opening of the IRPC.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: The main works contract with Baulderstone Hornibrook Pty Ltd (BHPL) was awarded for a value of $207.9 million.

The main works contract requires the contractor to meet a target sum for the value of subcontracts to be awarded to local Christmas Island businesses. The target sum was nominated as part of the contractorâs tender and is linked to financial incentives in the contract if the target is exceeded and a financial disincentive if the target sum is not met.

Approximately forty-eight of the one hundred people currently employed by BHPL are local employees. BHPL has engaged one trainee through the Indian Ocean Group Training (IOGT) Scheme. There are continuing negotiations between subcontractors and IOGT for the engagement of trainees and apprentices.

Practical completion of the IRPC is expected in the third quarter of 2006. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has advised that the IRPC will be commissioned in the 3 months following the completion of construction. Following commissioning the facility will be ready to operate.

It is not our practice to make public the specific obligations and commitments of these memorandums of understanding.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

quote.para: What sum will be allocated to the development and or purchase of facial biometric identification technology in 2005-2006.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:
asked the Minister for Trade, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

quote.para: What measures have been taken to facilitate trade with Thailand following the implementation of the Thailand-Australia Free Trade Agreement and what sum was allocated to each measure for 2005.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: The Government has maintained an active information and business outreach program on TAFTA, with Austrade/DFAT conducting seminars for Australian business in all capital cities in the lead up to the Agreementâs entry into force on 1 January 2005. DFAT has also distributed over 2,000 copies of the Business Guide to TAFTA, developed a TAFTA exporter webpage, and conducted training programs for the TAFTA Authorised Bodies (ACCI and AiG), customs brokers and others. The Government continues to provide advice direct to Australian companies on how to take advantage of the benefits offered by the Agreement and is also facilitating trade through effective use of TAFTAâs functional committees.

The cost of the publication âAustralia-Thailand Free Trade Agreement â Benefits for Australian Exportersâ was $18,016. The cost of production of the TAFTA Information Brochure was $8,040.23. The costs of the âBusiness Guide to TAFTAâ was approximately $27,000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Have Australiaâs missions in South East Asia sought their host government views on Australian participation on the East Asian Summit; if so, when did the discussions with host governments first take place.
Have South East Asian governments offered advice or views on how Australia should proceed to secure an invitation to the East Asian Summit; if so, what was that advice.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Government to government discussions are confidential.
ASEAN Foreign Ministers met on 10 April in the Philippines and agreed on three criteria for participation in the East Asia Summit:
- substantive relations with ASEAN;
- full Dialogue Partner status;
- and a commitment to accede to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Did the Australian Embassy in Tokyo discuss with the Japanese Government the reasons behind Japanâs decision to sign the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation (TAC).
Did Japan express any concerns about the TAC; if so, how did Japan reconcile its concerns about the treaty with its decision to sign it.

Have Australian diplomatic missions in South East Asia sought host government views on Australiaâs policy on the TAC; if so, when were these views first reported and can he provide the details of these views.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: and (3) Government-to-government discussions are confidential.
and (5) Relations between Japan and the United States are a matter for those two countries.
Discussion of the TAC has been part of our broader dialogue with ASEAN states. The details of those discussions form part of government-to-government interaction and are confidential.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Have across-the-board reductions in tariffs in Singapore made the concessions negotiated in the Australia-Singapore FTA redundant; if so, in which particular sectors.
Have across-the-board reductions in tariffs in Thailand made the concessions negotiated in the Thai-Australia FTA redundant; if so, in which particular sectors.
In which sectors does Australia still retain a preferential tariff rate in Singapore which is better than that facing other trading partners.
In which sectors does Australia still retain a preferential tariff rate in Thailand, which is better than that facing other trading partners.
What is the department doing to ensure that Thai FTA negotiations with Japan or the US do not erode Australiaâs advantage under the Thai-Australia FTA.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows :

item.para: Singapore is a free port. Australia benefits from SAFTA in other ways.
TAFTA ensures that Australian exporters will enjoy steadily lower tariffs from 1 January 2005, eventually reducing to zero for all items.
Singapore is a free port. Australia benefits from SAFTA in other ways.
Details can be obtained from DFATâs website www.dfat.gov.au.
We are monitoring negotiations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: During Prime Ministerial and Ministerial visits, do missions in developing countries import or arrange for the provision of special food to cater to the dietary preferences of the Prime Minister or a Minister; if so, what particular foods are arranged for these visits and at what cost to the Australian Government.

During Prime Ministerial and Ministerial visits do missions in developing countries import or arrange for the provision of wine, beer and other alcoholic beverages to cater to the preferences of the Prime Minister or a Minister.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Catering by missions for Prime Ministerial and Ministerial visits is arranged in the same way as has been the case under successive governments and takes into account specific dietary restrictions where applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: In which South East Asian countries has Australia held combined counter-terrorism military exercises like that held in Thailand in July 2004.
Are the Governments of ASEAN countries open to engaging in these exercises with Australia.
Are there further exercises planned in South East Asia.
What has been the follow-up with the Thai government from the exercise held in Thailand in July 2004.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: No other countries.

Australia has memoranda of understanding (MOUs) on counter-terrorism cooperation with Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand among ASEAN countries. These MOUs cover possible defence cooperation on counter-terrorism issues.
Australia has and will continue to engage closely with South East Asian countries on counter-terrorism issues, including for capacity building purposes and through exercises.

A bilateral counter-terrorism response seminar was held in Bangkok on 16-17 December 2004. This seminar, attended by a range of Australian and Thai government agencies, enabled both countries to gain a stronger appreciation of the otherâs crisis management and response arrangements for internal and international terrorist incidents.

para.inline: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in

item.para: How does the text of the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Pakistan differ from other Counter-terrorism MOUs signed between Australia and other countries in the region.
Does his department have a standard text or template agreement which it uses as a basis for negotiations.

What measures are being used to ensure that the capacity building and information exchanges under the Australia-Pakistan MOU on Counter-Terrorism are not used by Pakistani security authorities to perpetrate human rights abuses against Pakistani citizens.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The memorandum of understanding with Pakistan broadly follows the lines of other such memorandums. It will facilitate practical cooperation between the two countries in areas such as law enforcement, intelligence, security and border control.

There is a preferred format which is used as a basis for negotiation of our memorandums of understanding on counter-terrorism and certain provisions which the Government generally seeks to include. The precise details, however, of each memorandum of understanding reflect the priorities and circumstances of the country with which it is negotiated.

The Australian Government has made clear to the Government of Pakistan on numerous occasions the importance it attaches to the promotion and protection of human rights. The memorandum of understanding provides that cooperation pursuant to the memorandum be in conformity with the relevant provisions of national and international law, including international standards of human rights. The negotiation of memorandums of understanding on counter-terrorism should also be seen in the context of the Australian Governmentâs commitment to combating the very great threat to human rights that terrorism poses.

item.para: to (8) No DFAT staff had access to the Massage Program in Finance, therefore there was no cost incurred by DFAT in relation to the Program.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, in writing, on 23 June 2005.

item.para: What relaxation facilities and services, including sporting facilities, are provided to the staff of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT).
Does the Ministerâs department pay for any of these facilities; if so, which ones.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: to (9) DFAT staff do not have access to any relaxation facilities that are provided by Finance for its staff.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 23Â June 2005:

item.para: Has a product known as âAquacadabraâ been approved for use in Australian swimming pools.
Has this same substance been banned in Europe; if so why.
Has this substance been known to cause anaphylactic shock.
What scientific research was conducted by the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority before approving this product.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes, it was registered in 2003 as being similar to other products that were registered in the early 1980s prior to the formation of the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) - then the National Registration Authority (NRA).

The regulator for these products in the European Union (EU) has recently confirmed to the APVMA that the active ingredient in Aquacadabra, polihexanide, has not been banned in any of the member states of the EU. It is scheduled for review in the EU in 2007 with a report due in 2008. The principal manufacturer of this chemical, headquartered in the United Kingdom, has advised that it has not been banned anywhere in the world.

The APVMA is not aware of any reports of anaphylactic shock arising from the use of Aquacadabra in swimming pools or of any adverse reactions in Australia to products containing polihexanide. The United States Environment Protection Agency (US EPA) has not raised anaphylaxis or anaphylactic shock as issues of concern in its most recent overview of potential health effects of polihexanide on humans. No reports of anaphylaxis were found in its extensive databases.

In November 2004, the Office of Chemical Safety (OCS) in the Department of Human Health and Ageing conducted an evaluation of the scientific evidence and literature regarding anaphylaxis in humans associated with exposure to polihexanide in response to a request from the APVMA. The OCS evaluation found that anaphylaxis related to polihexanide is very rare with only two cases being identified internationally. These related to the application of a medical disinfectant containing 0.02% (200 mg/L) polihexanide to damaged skin.

The Therapeutic Goods Administrationâs Adverse Drug Reaction Section and Medical Devices Section have not received any reports of adverse reactions in Australia associated with the medical disinfectant and the APVMA is not aware of any adverse experience reports relating to the use of the chemical in swimming pools or other products.

The original product on which the registration of Lo-Chlor Aquacadabra Pool Sanitiser was granted was first registered prior to the foundation of the APVMA (originally known as the NRA) and therefore originally was assessed under the previous State and Territory registration systems. Products containing this active ingredient have been in use in Australia since the early 1980âs.

Further to the initial evaluation in relation to anaphylaxis conducted in 2004, the APVMA is currently undertaking a review of potential public health risks that might be associated with the uses of polihexanide, the active ingredient in Aquacadabra. This review follows a draft report from the US EPA of a potential carcinogenic effect in laboratory animals exposed to extremely high doses of polihexanide.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 23Â June 2005:

item.para: When was the last time the Australian Government reviewed its guidelines for the registration of chlorine and stabilised chlorine for swimming pools.
Is he or his department aware of any stabiliser products available in swimming pool shops that contain a warning on the label that reads âMay be fatal to childrenâ or words to that effect.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) does not provide specific registration guidelines for each individual active. An active is the substance in a formulated chemical product that is primarily responsible for the biological or other effects that make the product an agricultural or veterinary product. However, the APVMA released new guidelines for demonstrating the efficacy of swimming and spa pool sanitiser products in July 2004. In addition, the APVMA examined its criteria for other aspects of registration of pool sanitisers, including chlorine, and incorporated that outcome into the recent revision of the APVMA Manual of Requirements and Guidelines.

The APVMA (and the agencies that provide advice to it) regularly monitor international developments on chemicals that are contained in registered products. Additionally, registrants are required to advise the APVMA when they become aware of any adverse information on currently registered products. If information of concern comes to the APVMAâs attention, the APVMA has the power to reconsider and modify a productâs registration including stopping the use of a product or its active ingredient entirely if necessary. The APVMA is not aware of any recent information that would indicate a reconsideration of chlorine or stabilised chlorine products is necessary.

Prior to the formation of the APVMA, agreement was reached to exclude products that contain cyanuric acid as a chlorine stabiliser; that is, such products were declared not to be âagricultural chemical productsâ by the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Regulations. This agreement followed historical precedent set by the previous individual State and Territory systems of registration. Therefore, the APVMA does not regulate these products and does not have a database of their label information.

The APVMA, however, is aware that cyanuric acid is a schedule 5 poison in the Standard for the Uniform Scheduling of Drugs and Poisons (SUSDP). The Statesâ poisons legislation therefore requires the words âCAUTIONâ and âKEEP OUT OF REACH OF CHILDRENâ to be shown prominently on the top of the front panel of the label of any products containing this substance.
